axe.translation[0].definitions[0].defini: a tool with a heavy metal blade on the end of a long handle, used to cut down trees or split pieces of wood
axe.translation[1].definitions[0].defini: to suddenly dismiss someone from their job
axe.translation[1].definitions[0].exampl: There are plans to axe 2,600 staff.
axe.translation[1].definitions[1].defini: to get rid of a plan, system, or service, especially in order to save money
axe.translation[1].definitions[1].exampl: TV’s longest running show is to be axed.
axe.translation[2].definitions[0].defini: if a company axes jobs, it suddenly dismisses people in those jobs in order to reduce costs
axe.translation[2].definitions[0].exampl: The company announced plans to axe 300 jobs.
axe.translation[2].definitions[1].defini: to suddenly get rid of a plan or service, or reduce the amount of money spent on it
axe.translation[2].definitions[1].exampl: The airline’s transatlantic service is to be axed next month.
axe.translation[3].definitions[0].defini: if someone gets the axe or is given the axe, they are suddenly dismissed from their job because the company wants to reduce costs. If a plan, project, or service gets the axe, it is stopped in order to reduce costs
axe.translation[3].definitions[0].exampl: A lot of managers are now getting the axe.
axe.translation[3].definitions[1].defini: if the axe falls, someone is dismissed from their job or a plan, project, or service is stopped because a company needs to reduce its costs
axe.translation[3].definitions[1].exampl: The axe is now falling on people whose talents have been praised only months earlier.
